trebor

First of all, let us look at the definition of what an IC system is, according to Behe
 
 From Darwin's black box
 
 

 By irreducibly complex I mean a single system composed of several well-matched, interacting parts that contribute to the basic function, wherein the removal of any one of the parts causes the system to effectively cease functioning. An irreducibly complex system cannot be produced directly (that is, by continuously improving the initial function, which continues to work by the same mechanism) by slight, successive modifications of a precursor system, because any precursor to an irreducibly complex system that is missing a part is by definition nonfunctional. An irreducibly complex biological system, if there is such a thing, would be a powerful challenge to Darwinian evolution. (p. 39)
 

 
 Now, lets take a look at an experiment that can be repeatedly done in the lab that demonstrates that evolution of a IC system.
 
 This experiment was first done by Barry Hall of the University of Rochester in 1982. It was also described in Kennth Miller's book "Finding Darwin's God" (printed in 1999),
 I will point out this experiment was done 14 years before Behe's book "Darwin's black Box" was published.
 
 What Barry Hall did is remove the gene to digest lactose from some bacteria. He then let the bacteria grow until he had a culture of billions descended the single bacteria he had removed the gene from. He then subjected the bacteria colony to environmental pressures, and eventually only gave the culture lactose to survive. 
 
 For this to have worked, not just 1 gene had to evolve, but 3 different (i.e. multiply part) systems had to evolve. Not only did you need a gene for it, but you had to have a regulatory gene, and the evolution of a new enzyme reaction to allow lactose to get into the cell. In other words, this just wasn't a single gene that had to evolved, but a whole system.
 
 This experiment demolishes the idea that an IC system can not evolve, and destroy's Behe's premise that an IC system points to a designer.

post_info.post_title: Testable repeatable experiment showing the evolution of an IC system

Symbiote
Obviously, experiments of this kind act as a pagan ritual by which various divine entities are summoned and impart their intelligence, granting mercy to the poor baceria.
The Skeptic

What Barry Hall did is remove the gene to digest lactose from some bacteria. He then let the bacteria grow until he had a culture of billions descended the single bacteria he had removed the gene from. He then subjected the bacteria colony to environmental pressures, and eventually only gave the culture lactose to survive.
 
 For this to have worked, not just 1 gene had to evolve, but 3 different (i.e. multiply part) systems had to evolve. Not only did you need a gene for it, but you had to have a regulatory gene, and the evolution of a new enzyme reaction to allow lactose to get into the cell. In other words, this just wasn't a single gene that had to evolved, but a whole system.

 
 Hi trebor - 
 
 Have you actually read Hall's work, or are you simply taking Miller at his word?
 
 First, this is a significant misrepresentation of the actual experiment. Hall wrote in 1999: "All of the other functions for lactose metabolism, including lactose permease and the pathways for metabolism of glucose and galactose, the products of lactose hydrolysis, remain intact, thus re-acquisition of lactose utilization requires only the evolution of a new B-galactosidase function."[2] (my emphasis)
 
 Therefore, Miller's claim that an entire multiple part system was deleted is actually false, according to his own source. Instead, it turns out, only one part of the system (the B- galactosidase) was removed. In order to "re-activate" the B-galactosidase function, two separate mutations occurred in two separate genes: the so-called "evolved B-galactosidase" gene (ebg) and the repressor protein for ebg.
 
 Second, Hall introduced an artificial inducer into the growth medium, which was necessary for the survival of the mutated bacteria. Thus, vital steps in the "evolution" of said "system" were actually supported by intelligent intervention.
 
 Also, if you would like to see the biochemical details, here is an additional objection from Behe:
 
 
The nature of adaptive mutation aside, a strong reason to consider the lac/ebg results quite modest is that the ebg proteins--both the repressor and B-galactosidase--are homologous to the E. coli lac proteins and overlap the proteins in activity. Both of the unmutated ebg proteins already bind lactose. Binding of lactose even to the unmutated ebg repressor induces a 100-fold increase in synthesis of the ebg operon. (Hall 1982a) Even the unmutated ebg B-galactosidase can hydrolyze lactose at a level of about 10% that of a "Class II" mutant B-galactosidase that supports cell growth. (Hall 1999) These activities are not sufficient to permit growth of E. coli on lactose, but they already are present. The mutations reported by Hall simply enhance pre-existing activities of the proteins. In a recent paper (Hall 1999) Professor Hall pointed out that both the lac and ebg B-galactosidase enzymes are part of a family of highly-conserved B-galactosidases, identical at 13 of 15 active site amino acid residues, which apparently diverged by gene duplication more than two billion years ago. The two mutations in ebg B-galactosidase that increase its ability to hydrolyze lactose change two nonidentical residues back to those of other B-galactosidases in ebg's phylogenetic class, so that their active sites are identical. Thus--before any experiments were done--the ebg active site was already a near-duplicate of other B-galactosidases, and only became more active by becoming a complete duplicate. Significantly, by phylogenetic analysis Hall concluded that those two mutations are the only ones in E. coli that confer the ability to hydrolyze lactose. 
 The phylogenetic evidence indicates that either Asp-92 and Cys/Trp-977 are the only acceptable amino acids at those positions, or that all of the single base substitutions that might be on the pathway to other amino acid replacements at those sites are so deleterious that they constitute a deep selective valley that has not been traversed in the 2 billion years since those proteins diverged from a common ancestor. (Hall 1999)

 All of this is really complex, but when the tire meats the road, we see that this is not an example of the evolution of an irreducibly complex system.
 
  References:
 
 1. Hall, B. G. (1999). Experimental evolution of ebg enzyme provides clues about the evolution of catalysis and to evolutionary potential. FEMS Microbiology Letters 174, 1-8. As cited by Michael Behe a http://www.arn.org/docs/behe/mb_trueacidtest.htm
trebor

 Have you actually read Hall's work, or are you simply taking Miller at his word?
 
 First, this is a significant misrepresentation of the actual experiment. Hall wrote in 1999: "All of the other functions for lactose metabolism, including lactose permease and the pathways for metabolism of glucose and galactose, the products of lactose hydrolysis, remain intact, thus re-acquisition of lactose utilization requires only the evolution of a new B-galactosidase function."[2] (my emphasis)

 All of this is really complex, but when the tire meats the road, we see that this is not an example of the evolution of an irreducibly complex system.

 1. Hall, B. G. (1999). Experimental evolution of ebg enzyme provides clues about the evolution of catalysis and to evolutionary potential. FEMS Microbiology Letters 174, 1-8. As cited by Michael Behe a http://www.arn.org/docs/behe/mb_trueacidtest.htm

 
 Ah.. quote mining I see, 
 
 There are a number of flaws in Behe's analysis. One, Hall did not 'choose' what mutation would work. Second of all, when the gene was removed, it didn't merely recreate that specific gene. It eliminated a functioning of a full system. If Behe's critisim was correct, then for the hall experiment to work,
 only one item had to evolved, and the compenents in the current structure would have worked.
 
 However, that isn't what happened. You see, a new gene to work, three different compentets had to evolved to replace it. In other words, the original strucutre was rendered non-working, and it was totally replaced by 3 new compentes. (a brand new multipart system).
 
 The bacteris got 
 1) A new galactosidase enzyme
 2) A new lac permase gene
 3) a new way to activate the lac permease gene.
 
 The deletion of the old gene destroyed the old structure. 3 new sections had to evolved for a brand new gene to work. 
 
 For Kenneth's Miller's response to 'The Acid Test', you can go to 
 http://www.millerandlevine.com/km/evol/DI/AcidTest.html
The Skeptic

 If I made a mistake as to his intent, please point it out, instead of beating around the bush.
 
 
One, Hall did not 'choose' what mutation would work.

 
 Of course he didn't. He simply set up conditions that would not occur in the real world in order to allow the system to evolve. That is intelligent intervention, not evolution.
 
 
If Behe's critisim was correct, then for the hall experiment to work,
 only one item had to evolved, and the compenents in the current structure would have worked.
 
 However, that isn't what happened. You see, a new gene to work, three different compentets had to evolved to replace it. In other words, the original strucutre was rendered non-working, and it was totally replaced by 3 new compentes. (a brand new multipart system).
 
 The bacteris got 
 1) A new galactosidase enzyme
 2) A new lac permase gene
 3) a new way to activate the lac permease gene.
 
 The deletion of the old gene destroyed the old structure. 3 new sections had to evolved for a brand new gene to work.

 
 You are misrepresenting Behe, here. He did not claim that the B-galactosidase function is simply one protein - that would be ridiculous. It is an entire function. 
 
 Second, as Behe pointed out (and as Miller ignored), the parts that were used to replace the B- galactosidase function were already in the system. They simply were activated by the mutations.
 
 Lastly, and perhaps more importantly, it remains to be proven that said system was irreducibly complex at all. The full definition of irreducible complexity was laid out at the beginning of the thread. Said system meets the basics of irreducible complexity (ie, if one part is removed the system stops working). However, no evidence has been presented showing that it meets the other sections of the definition. (ie, "well-matched" parts) In fact, according to Behe, the system that "evolved" lacked well-matched parts. Miller again ignored this.
trebor

Of course he didn't. He simply set up conditions that would not occur in the real world in order to allow the system to evolve. That is intelligent intervention, not evolution.
 

 
 THat is a very bogus claim. Yes, he set up controled conditions. However, Hall did not choose which specific bateria would reproduce, nor did he guide the mutations. He just showed that organisms will adapt to environmental stress.
 
 For your claim to be true, you have to explain away the evolution of the nylon digesting bacteria, and the petrolium digesting bacteria, similar systems that developed in the wild.
 
 

 You are misrepresenting Behe, here. He did not claim that the B-galactosidase function is simply one protein - that would be ridiculous. It is an entire function. 
 

 
 Yet, he did claim that only one function was removed.. It was HE that misrepresented the experiment, and Kenneth Miller.
 
 

 Second, as Behe pointed out (and as Miller ignored), the parts that were used to replace the B- galactosidase function were already in the system. They simply were activated by the mutations.
 

 
 And, as miller pointed out, that is how evolution works. Small changes from preexisting parts providing new function. In this case, the function was to beable to digest lactose.. a function that was not there before. 
 
 

 
 Lastly, and perhaps more importantly, it remains to be proven that said system was irreducibly complex at all. None of the 'functions' that Behe used in his book 'Darwin's black box' as being "Irreducible complex" meet the defintions as Behe has given, because each and every example in his book has been shown to be reducibile complex. 
 
 If that is not a 'irrecubile complex' system.. show me a test to be able to determine if any specific process is irreducible complex, and then show that particular function could not evolve naturaly. 
 
 The specific function matches Behe's defnition. Do you want to play the 'Oh. but wait' game? If so.. come out with a test that can PROVE any function is 
 "irreducible complex". The bacteria flagiullum is not IC.. that has been proven over and over again.
The Skeptic

And, as miller pointed out, that is how evolution works. Small changes from preexisting parts providing new function. In this case, the function was to beable to digest lactose.. a function that was not there before.

 
 I certainly wasn't claiming that what we are dealing with isn't a "change." My point is that only a small part of a vast, non-irreducibly complex system was deactivated and replaced because of conditions set up by an intelligent designer. That simply doesn't demonstrate that actual irreducibly complex systems such as those described in Behe's book can evolve by chance.
 
 
For your claim to be true, you have to explain away the evolution of the nylon digesting bacteria, and the petrolium digesting bacteria, similar systems that developed in the wild.

 
 From what I understand, both of those systems where the result of the deletion of a repressor, not the evolution of a new system.
 
 
Again, according to Behe's own definition, it is IC. One compenetn was removed, and the entire multipart function fails. If that is not what IC is, then you are moving the goal posts.

 
 Rather, you are shooting at the wrong goal to begin with. Look at the definition of irreducible complexity that you posted at the beginning of the thread. There is more to it that simply not being able to remove the parts - it must be a closely fitting system. The definition is specific because Behe and other ID advocates realize that some non-closely fitting systems could possibly evolve.
 
 
None of the 'functions' that Behe used in his book 'Darwin's black box' as being "Irreducible complex" meet the defintions as Behe has given, because each and every example in his book has been shown to be reducibile complex

 
 Do you really expect me to just throw up my hands and say "Gee, trebor, I guess I'll just take your word on it?" :)

 You are moving the goalposts again. The structure that was described was
 a complex multipart system within it self. You had three indepentand parts that had to cooperate and evolve for the bacteria to digeest lactose.
 
 Let us review Behe's definition of 'IC' again.
 

 By irreducibly complex I mean a single system composed of several well-matched, interacting parts that contribute to the basic function, wherein the removal of any one of the parts causes the system to effectively cease functioning. An irreducibly complex system cannot be produced directly (that is, by continuously improving the initial function, which continues to work by the same mechanism) by slight, successive modifications of a precursor system, because any precursor to an irreducibly complex system that is missing a part is by definition nonfunctional. An irreducibly complex biological system, if there is such a thing, would be a powerful challenge to Darwinian evolution. (p. 39)
 

 
 The system to allow the digestion of lactose was 1) multipoart 2) interacting
 that contribute to a basic function (the digesting of lactose), where the removal of any one of the parts (the removal of the one gene) causes the sysetm to effectively cease functioning (it can't digest lactose anymore).
 
 By Behe's definition, the abiltiy to digest lactose was a multifunction system and irreducibley complex. And, by Behe's own definition, the function that evolved to replace the missing gene was a brand new function that did not use any part of the old function that was rendered useless by the removal of the ability to digest lactose.

 This is an important point. Evolution does not mean "from less complex to more complex". A system which cannot (or is unlikely to) be built up from less complex systems may well be built up from more complex systems.
 
 We may imagine 3 evolved "functions" of an organism hardwired into genetic code through some sets of genes, and these functions are built up from simple bases. We may then conceive of a new function evolving through mutations which remove some part of these functions (eg repressor genes), resulting in an "irreducibly complex" system. I do not know if such systems exist, however it does not seem unlikely given the immense diversity of genetics on earth (and my limited understanding of genetics).

In a real IC system (like the bacterial flagellum), the parts fit together very closely. That is why Behe said in his definition that the parts must be "well-matched."

 Furthermore, that sort of evolution is not the sort of evolution that would be required to make all life come from a common ancestor. No one makes money by cutting their money up. Likewise, the first life form could not have increased into the complexity that we see today by constantly loosing and disabling parts.

 If the system meets the following criteria, it is IC: "a single system composed of several well-matched, interacting parts that contribute to the basic function, wherein the removal of any one of the parts causes the system to effectively cease functioning." Scientific research has revealed that many systems in the cell meet those criteria - no new experiment is needed, only knowledge of the progress of biochemical research over the last fifty some years.

 Walking-fish:
 I can't comment on the genetics & biochemistry involved, since I haven't read the article. But I do take issue with the assertion that setting up laboratory conditions counts as "Intelligent Design". Unless the researchers actually inserted a specific gene into an organism by some process of genetic engineering, it still counts as evolution by mutation & natural selection. I mean, setting up the conditions for selection is not the same as designing the gene.
